title: The Design, Creation and Survival of Democratic Laws
descriptions:
Abstract:

The DEMOLAW project aims to revolutionize our understanding of the intricacies involved in the legislative processes of democratic societies. At the heart of a functioning democracy lies the crucial task of integrating diverse perspectives into cohesive laws—a task that has become increasingly complex in today's politically charged environment. Despite the profound impact legislation has on both the daily lives of citizens and the effectiveness of democratic governance, the connection between the design, enactment, and endurance of laws remains largely unexplored.

This pioneering initiative will scrutinize legislative texts from the United States, the United Kingdom, and the European Union using advanced computational techniques to dissect three pivotal questions: the empirical measurement of law design through textual attributes, the reasons behind variations in law design across different laws, policy areas, and political systems, and the factors contributing to the stability or constant evolution of laws.

The DEMOLAW project's first breakthrough contribution is the development of a new conceptual framework for understanding the architecture of democratic laws. By focusing on two fundamental dimensions, versatility and precision, the project will deliver unprecedented insights into the substantive content of legislation. This approach allows for a pioneering comparative analysis of legislative outputs, offering a holistic view of policy-making across various domains and systems over time.

Secondly, by proposing and evaluating an integrated theoretical model, the project aims to advance the academic discourse in comparative public policy by elucidating both the genesis and the persistence of democratic laws.

Lastly, the project will set a new standard in legislative studies with its innovative methodological approach. By harnessing computational analysis, DEMOLAW will expand the possibilities for examining the content and decision-making processes behind democratic legislation, thereby making a profound contribution to the field.

**Description:**

Democracies are constantly confronted with the challenging task of merging widely diverging worldviews, interests and values into coherent legislation. Given the increasingly hostile political climate around the world, solving this task has never been more difficult and more important than today. Yet, despite the crucial relevance of laws for our daily lives and the legitimacy and effectiveness of democratic government, our understanding of how the design, creation and long-term survival of legislation are related is still very limited. The DEMOLAW project analyses legislative texts in three different political systems (US, UK, EU) with cutting-edge computational methods to answer three major research questions: (1) Which conceptual dimensions capture the design of a law and how can we exploit textual properties of law texts to measure these dimensions empirically? (2) Why does the design of democratic legislation vary across laws, policy domains and political systems?
